title: Design's influence on luxury
text:
And today there’s the predominance of technology, which can create a pervading pressure to be seen with the latest gadgets.

If there’s one commonality to the philosophy of luxury brands, it’s about making life easier or better, and creating the opportunity for personal expression.

Timeless luxury

It’s why more classical forms of luxury, such as watchmaking, have endured regardless of changing trends and influences.

The hallmark of horological mastery has for a long time carried the ‘Made in Switzerland’ label. Yet following centuries of tradition Nicholoas Hack, named after its founder, has emerged as the first company to manufacturer watches in Australia.

While the company’s history is short compared with many of the more famous watch brands, its story is already a compelling one so far. Last year the brand released the first series of 25 timepieces in which the “very DNA of the watch”, such as the main plate and bridges, were Australian made.

“Modern digital technology is not a replacement for sophistication, and by sophistication we mean the appreciation for craftsmen’s ability to turn a piece of metal into high-precision yet artistic instruments,” says Hacko, explaining why traditional watches have continued to be so popular in an era of smartphones and watches.

“A mechanical watch is a miracle of mechanical engineering. It comes with high expectations of time accurately 24/7 without any rest while being in constant motion exposed to outside forces, temperature changes and with almost no servicing.

“While we are quite happy to replace our mobile phone every two to three years, we expect a mechanical watch to last for 50 or 100 years. I cannot think of any piece of machinery – digital or mechanical – that will have to meet such requirements.”

Hacko says the ultimate challenge for a watchmaker is to manufacture components at very tight tolerances, often at micron level. Manufacturing a titanium watch main plate, for example, requires 24 different tools and three types of jig to hold it in place.

The luxury of precision time by Nicholas Hacko. Supplied.

The machining time and hand-finishing process takes nearly a full working day – and the consequence of just one mistake from a single tool is restarting the entire process from scratch. It’s a labour of love to bring the right time to a watch wearer’s every day.

The value of luxury

Swedish car maker Volvo – as part of its sustainability initiative, the ‘omtanke’ philosophy which focuses on ways in which to view the world differently – is aiming by 2025 to give back a week of quality time every year to owners of its cars through autonomous drive technology.

Tisha Johnson, the company’s head of interior design, views advances in technology as the underpinnings of big cultural trends today.

“People are expecting products to give back to them as never before,” says Johnson. “Wellbeing, safety and security, and time are three examples of very big focus areas for people around the world.

“Therefore, we created our vertical centre touchscreen to improve interaction within the car. We’ve also presented the 360c concept, which leverages cutting-edge tech in order to give back time and peace of mind.

“We’ve done it in a way that again isn’t focused on the technology itself but rather what value we can bring back to people every day.

“Good technology will continue to help customers experience Volvo’s rich Scandinavian design.”

Scandinavian design is renowned for its minimalist approach and the way it strives to balance form and function.

And as the only Scandinavian car maker in the world, it gives Volvo a distinctive look compared with rivals from Germany, England and Japan.

A seat at the table of luxury

Wood is synonymous with Scandinavian furniture, though the use of it in the creative process isn’t exclusive to the likes of Sweden and Denmark, of course.

Australian furniture designer Mark Tuckey has been specialising in the age-old material of timber since the very early 1990s. Recycled timber furniture met his desires to work with something that was environmentally friendly and also allowed him to do something creative.

“I love timber,” says Mark passionately. “The look, the smell, the feel, the inherent usefulness and adaptability of it; it’s an incredible, naturally occurring part of nature.

Mark Tuckey uses natural materials to create luxury furniture. Supplied.

“Mostly, old timbers have an inherent structural integrity that new timbers don’t as new timbers are fast-grown with hormones and cut down whilst young so never get the same density.”

Asked why wood evokes such a sense of luxury in furniture, as well as other design pieces, Tuckey offers a passionate explanation.

“Wood is real. It’s natural. It smells, looks and feels like luxury. It's authentic, nature has gifted us an amazing resource. Wood stands up on its own without needing much processing; its calm. That’s luxury to me.”

Omtanke isn’t just a word. It’s a lens through which you can view the world, and see things differently. It’s a new perspective. A considerate, more caring one. Omtanke shines a brighter light on the things that really matter, and that helps us focus on making those things better. On making the world better. For everyone. Omtanke. We welcome you to try it. volvocars.com.au
description: Luxury is a term that can be difficult to define, and its interpretation is certainly dictated by individual perspectives.
